program_info.title: Realistic 15-Month Planche Training Program
realistic_expectations: Full planche is achievable for some, but advanced tuck or straddle is more realistic for most
Individual progress varies based on genetics, training history, and consistency
Some athletes may need 18-24+ months for full planche
Focus on injury-free progression over speed
important_notes: Warm up 10-15 minutes before every session
Perfect form is mandatory - never sacrifice form for longer holds
If you feel joint pain (not muscle fatigue), stop and rest
Eat adequate protein (1.6-2g per kg bodyweight)

exercises: Pull-up negatives: 4 sets of 3-5 reps (5 sec descent)
Hollow body hold: 3 sets of 20-30 seconds
Hollow body hold: 3 sets of 30 seconds
Pseudo planche push-ups (slight lean): 3 sets of 5-8 reps
Plank shoulder taps: 3 sets of 16 taps total
Crow pose practice: 5 attempts of 5-10 seconds
Handstand wall hold: 3 sets of 15-20 seconds
Pseudo planche push-ups: 4 sets of 6-8 reps
Frog stand: 4 sets of max hold (aim 5-10 sec)
Archer rows: 3 sets of 6 each side
Hanging knee raises: 3 sets of 8 reps
Tuck L-sit attempts: 4 sets of 10-15 seconds
Pseudo planche holds: 4 sets of 12-15 seconds
Wide grip pull-ups: 3 sets of 4-5 reps
Frog stand: 5 sets of max hold
Tuck planche attempts: 5 sets of max hold (aim 3-6 sec)
Pseudo planche push-ups: 4 sets of 8-10 reps
Tuck front lever holds: 4 sets of 8-12 seconds
Hanging leg raises: 3 sets of 8 reps
Tuck planche negatives: 3 sets of 4 reps
Archer pull-ups: 3 sets of 4 each side
Skin the cat: 3 sets of 3-5 reps
Tuck planche: 6 sets of max hold
Tuck planche negatives: 4 sets of 3-4 reps
Pseudo planche push-ups: 4 sets of 10 reps
Advanced tuck front lever: 4 sets of 10-12 seconds
Front lever rows (tuck): 3 sets of 4-5 reps
Full L-sit attempts: 4 sets of 20-30 seconds
Tuck planche holds: 4 sets of 10 seconds
Tuck planche push-ups: 4 sets to failure
Advanced tuck planche: 5 sets of max hold (aim 4-7 sec)
Advanced tuck leans: 4 sets of 15-20 seconds
Tuck planche push-ups: 4 sets of 4-6 reps
Archer pull-ups: 3 sets of 5 each side
Straddle front lever: 4 sets of 8-12 seconds
One-arm hang: 3 sets of 10 seconds each
Pseudo planche explosive: 4 sets of 6 reps
One-arm pull-up progressions: 4 sets each side
Advanced tuck planche: 6 sets max hold
Straddle planche attempts: 5 sets max hold (aim 2-4 sec)
Planche push-ups (adv tuck): 4 sets of 6-8 reps
Full front lever: 4 sets of 8-12 seconds
Front lever rows: 3 sets of 5 reps
Handstand press negatives: 3 sets of 4 reps
Straddle planche negatives: 4 sets of 4 seconds
Straddle planche: 6 sets of max hold (aim 5-8 sec)
Front lever touch: 3 sets of 4 reps
Straddle planche on parallettes: 4 sets of 6-8 sec
Pseudo planche push-ups: 4 sets of 12 reps
One-arm pull-up work: 4 sets each side
One-leg attempts: 4 sets max each leg (aim 3-5 sec)
Straddle to tuck: 3 sets of 4 transitions
Front lever pull-ups: 3 sets of 4 reps
Straddle planche push-ups: 5 sets to failure
Full planche attempts: 5 sets max (aim 2-4 sec)
One-leg planche: 4 sets of 6-8 sec each
Full planche leans: 4 sets of 15 seconds
Iron Cross leans: 3 sets of 12 seconds
Back lever to front lever: 3 sets of 3 transitions
Full planche leans: 4 sets of 20 seconds
One-leg to full transitions: 3 sets of 3 each
Full planche negatives: 4 sets of 4 reps
One-arm hang: 4 sets of 40 sec each
Full planche push-ups: 4 sets of 2-3 reps
Weighted pull-ups (very heavy): 5 sets of 4 reps
Iron Cross on rings: 4 sets max
Ring dips (full RTO): 4 sets of 12 reps
Full planche on parallettes: 4 sets of 8 sec
Full planche perfect form: 5 sets of 12+ seconds
Full planche push-ups: 4 sets of 4-5 reps
Muscle-ups: 4 sets of 10 reps each type
Full planche push-ups: 4 sets of 6-7 reps
Full planche max: push for 15+ sec
Full planche push-ups: 4 sets of 8+ reps
Full planche push-ups: 4 sets of 10+ reps

most_likely_outcomes: Full planche: 3-10 seconds (achievable for some, requires dedication)
Full planche 15+ seconds: exceptional achievement, not guaranteed
individual_factors: Genetics play a significant role in planche progression
Arm length, shoulder structure affect difficulty significantly
Consistency is the most important factor
Some may need 18-24+ months for full planche
realistic_outcome_expectations.success_criteria: Success is measured by YOUR progress, not arbitrary timelines. If you achieve advanced tuck or straddle planche, you've succeeded tremendously.

nutrition_guidelines.calories: Slight surplus if building, maintenance for skill
nutrition_guidelines.supplements: Optional: Creatine, Omega-3, Vitamin D, Magnesium

progress_tracking.monthly: Photos and videos from same angles

warning_signs: Persistent wrist pain - reduce volume, add rehab
Shoulder impingement - check form, see professional
Elbow tendonitis - rest and rehab required
safety_notes.injury_protocol: If injured, rest 1-2 weeks minimum, see physiotherapist

final_message: This is a REALISTIC 15-month journey. Full planche is an elite skill that takes most people 2-3+ years. If you achieve straddle planche with excellent form, you're in the top 1% of fitness. Focus on YOUR progress, not timelines. Stay consistent, avoid injury, and celebrate every milestone. The journey itself transforms you into an exceptional athlete. Trust the process!
